    <item>
      <title>Everton hope to tempt Ronald Koeman with lure of record transfer budget</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/everton-ronald-koeman-roberto-martinez-goodison-park-</link>
      <description>• Roberto Martínez fired after three seasons in the job<br />• Blues draw up a working shortlist of Dutchmen<br /><p>Everton want Ronald Koeman to succeed Roberto Martínez and hope to lure the Southampton coach with the promise of the biggest transfer budget in their history.</p><p>Farhad Moshiri, Everton’s new major shareholder, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/roberto-martinez-sacked-everton" title="">sacked Martínez on Thursday</a> and has earmarked Southampton’s manager as his preferred replacement. The British-Iranian billionaire faces a challenge to prise the 53-year-old from St&nbsp;Mary’s, however, even with Koeman yet to commit to a new contract and having just over 12 months remaining on his deal.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/everton-ronald-koeman-roberto-martinez-goodison-park-">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Rafael Benítez tempted by Newcastle stay after ‘productive’ talks</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/rafael-benitez-newcastle-tempted-productive-talks</link>
      <description>• Manager to demand written assurances of promises made in negotiations<br />• Benítez has relegation clause in contract which allows him to leave<p>Rafael Benítez is strongly tempted by the challenge of leading Newcastle out of the Championship but despite “productive” talks with Lee Charnley, the newly relegated club’s managing director, on Thursday afternoon, much needs to be negotiated before any decision is reached.</p><p>It is understood that Benítez will demand written assurances of promises made during the ongoing discussions but, with his own immediate future seeming inextricably linked to that of the Spaniard, Charnley has a keen interest in persuading Steve McClaren’s successor to ignore the break option in his three-year contract.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/rafael-benitez-newcastle-tempted-productive-talks">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Police watchdog to investigate Hillsborough inquest spin claims</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/police-watchdog-ipcc-investigate-hillsborough-inquest-spin-claims</link>
      <description><p>South Yorkshire police communications specialist says she was given ‘unethical’ instructions to try to influence coverage</p><p>The Independent Police Complaints Commission has launched an investigation into allegations that South Yorkshire police <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/05/south-yorkshire-police-tried-to-spin-evidence-at-hillsborough-inquests">tried to influence</a> daily media coverage of the Hillsborough inquests and spin what the force considered to be evidence favourable to it.</p><p>Hayley Court, a communications specialist hired by South Yorkshire police in 2014 specifically to work on the inquests, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/05/south-yorkshire-police-tried-to-spin-evidence-at-hillsborough-inquests">told the Guardian last week</a> that she believed she had been given “unethical” instructions to spin coverage for the force. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/police-watchdog-ipcc-investigate-hillsborough-inquest-spin-claims">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>France select Olivier Giroud for Euro 2016 but Hatem Ben Arfa misses out</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/france-squad-euro-2016-olivier-giroud-ben-arfa</link>
      <description>• Coach Didier Deschamps selects Dimitri Payet and N’Golo Kanté<br />• Former Newcastle forward Ben Arfa named on standby list<p>The France coach Didier Deschamps picked the Arsenal striker Olivier Giroud on Thursday for his 23-man squad for Euro 2016, which France will host, only naming the in-form forward Hatem Ben Arfa as a reserve.</p><p>Giroud, recovering from a lean spell for his club, is one of six forwards in the squad alongside Antoine Griezmann, Dimitri Payet, Anthony Martial, Kingsley Coman and Andre-Pierre Gignac.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/france-squad-euro-2016-olivier-giroud-ben-arfa">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sunderland relegate Newcastle and Norwich – Football Weekly Extra</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/audio/2016/may/12/sunderland-relegate-newcastle-norwich-football-weekly-extra-podcast</link>
      <description><p>Sam Allardyce saves his Premier League skin again. Plus, the battle for the Champions League spots, John Terry’s Stamford Bridge barbecue and the curious case of Joey Barton’s Championship winner’s medal </p><p>On today’s<strong> Football Weekly Extra</strong>, <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/acjimbo">AC Jimbo</a></strong> is joined by the triple threat of <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/bglendenning">Barry Glendenning</a></strong>, <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/john_ashdown">John Ashdown</a></strong> and <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/greggbakowski">Gregg Bakowski</a></strong> to look back on <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sunderland-everton-premier-league-match-report">Sunderland’s victory at Everton</a>, a result which <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/11/sam-allardyce-sunderland-escape-route-everton-rafael-benitez">confirmed the relegations of both Newcastle and Norwich</a>. <a href="http://www.claretandhugh.info/wp-content/uploads/Big-Sam_800x400-800x380.jpg">Oh, Big Sam, how could you</a>?</p><p>With the top and the bottom of the Premier League therefore sorted, the drama of the final weekend involves <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/liverpool-manchester-united-hopes-european-hopes">the Champions League spots</a>. Will <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/09/tottenham-finishing-above-arsenal-good-feeling-harry-kane">Arsenal pip Spurs</a> to second place? Will it be United or City who finish fourth? Or will <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/west-ham-david-sullivan-poor-judgement-supporters">West Ham inflict yet damage pain on United’s coach</a>? (That’s LVG, people).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/audio/2016/may/12/sunderland-relegate-newcastle-norwich-football-weekly-extra-podcast">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sunderland’s Sam Allardyce calls on Ellis Short to ‘think bigger’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/sunderland-sam-allardyce-ellis-short-meeting</link>
      <description>• Allardyce preparing for ‘critical’ meeting with Sunderland owner<br />• ‘We have to think much bigger, have much more ambition’<p>Sam Allardyce never made it home after <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sunderland-everton-premier-league-match-report">Sunderland’s survival-securing home win against Everton</a> on Wednesday night. Instead the manager spent “a few” convivial hours drinking with Ellis Short, the owner, but the pair are likely to be stone cold sober when they meet next week to discuss their summer transfer budget and strategy.</p><p>“I’m only just overcoming a hangover,” said Allardyce, who checked into a hotel in the early hours of Thursday. “But my next meeting with Ellis will be critical as to whether we struggle again next season or not. The big thing is the new players we bring in and how we can improve the team. We have to move away from the fact that we’re all so happy at being heroes for surviving. We have to think much bigger, have much more ambition.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/sunderland-sam-allardyce-ellis-short-meeting">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Portsmouth’s Cook angry with Jamille Matt after Plymouth playoffs draw</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/porstmouth-plymouth-paul-cook-playoffs</link>
      <description><p>The Portsmouth manager Paul Cook was furious with Jamille Matt after the Plymouth striker appeared to head-butt Michael Doyle during the 2-2 play-off semi-final first-leg draw at Fratton Park.</p><p>A fuming Cook was sent to the stands along with the Argyle assistant manager Paul Wootton in the immediate aftermath to the incident.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/porstmouth-plymouth-paul-cook-playoffs">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Borussia Dortmund sign Ousmane Dembélé from Rennes on five-year deal</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/borussia-dortmund-sign-ousmane-dembele-from-rennes-on-five-year-deal</link>
      <description>• The 18-year-old is considered one of best young players in Europe<br />• ‘Concept at Borussia has totally convinced me,’ says Dembélé<p>Borussia Dortmund have signed the highly rated <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/23/ousmane-dembele-football-hottest-property-rennes-bayern-munich-ligue-1" title="">Ousmane Dembélé</a> from Rennes for an undisclosed fee. The 18-year-old, who had been watched by a host of European clubs, has signed a five-year contract with the Bundesliga club.</p><p>This season, the forward has scored 12 goals in Ligue 1 in 25 games and provided five assists. He was voted the best young player in France this season. “Dortmund have looked at me for a long time and have always been in close contact with me and their conduct has really impressed me,” he said.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/borussia-dortmund-sign-ousmane-dembele-from-rennes-on-five-year-deal">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Danny Simpson to miss out on Leicester title celebrations after curfew order</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/danny-simpson-leicester-city-curfew-title-celebrations</link>
      <description>• Full-back ordered to wear ankle tag and be in by 10pm<br />• Defender did only half community service for assaulting ex-girlfriend<br /><p>The Leicester City full-back Danny Simpson will miss part of the title-winning celebrations and the club’s end-of-season party after a judge ordered he must serve a curfew immediately for assaulting his ex-girlfriend.</p><p>Simpson, 29, had only done half of the 300 hours he was sentenced to last June for assaulting Stephanie Ward, the mother of his child, in a row at their house in Worsley, Greater Manchester, in December 2014.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/danny-simpson-leicester-city-curfew-title-celebrations">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Sam Allardyce in dance mode after ‘one of my greatest achievements’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sam-allardyce-sunderland-greatest-achievement</link>
      <description><p>• Allardyce: ‘To be safe with one game to go is pretty miraculous’<br>• Sunderland manager now aims to stop cycle of survival struggles</p><p>Sam Allardyce dad-danced across the pitch as his Sunderland side celebrated their latest escape from relegation on a night when Newcastle United and Norwich City were condemned to the Championship.</p><p>Sunderland’s 3-0 win against Roberto Martínez’s struggling Everton was sufficient to end survival hopes on Tyneside and in Norfolk. Although Alex Neil’s side defeated <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/norwich-city-watford-premier-league-match-report">Watford 4-2 at Carrow Road</a> it was not enough to save his team, who go down with Aston Villa and Newcastle.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sam-allardyce-sunderland-greatest-achievement">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/manuel-pellegrini-manchester-city-manager-data</link>
      <description>• Departing manager produces figures to show his success at City<br />• Pellegrini: ‘The only thing we couldn’t be best at was defence’<p>Manuel Pellegrini has prepared for his departure from Manchester City by making a strong defence of his record at the club and supplying what he considers hard evidence to support his claims that his three-year reign should not be regarded as disappointing.</p><p>Pellegrini will take charge of his final game, at Swansea City on Sunday, with the most expensively assembled team in the Premier League <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/11/pep-guardiola-manchester-city-europa-league-champions-league-football" title="">still not assured of being in the Champions League</a> when Pep Guardiola takes over in the summer.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/manuel-pellegrini-manchester-city-manager-data">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Mauricio Pochettino signs Tottenham contract extension until 2021</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/mauricio-pochettino-signs-new-deal-future-tottenham-2021</link>
      <description>• Pochettino had been linked with move to Manchester United<br />• Several key players now expected to commit to long-term deals<p>Mauricio Pochettino has signed his new five-year contract at Tottenham Hotspur and a clutch of key players are now expected to commit to longer-term deals at the club.</p><p>The manager <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/video/2016/apr/29/mauricio-pochettino-extends-tottenham-contract-to-2021-video" title="">announced two weeks ago</a> that he had reached a verbal agreement with the chairman, Daniel Levy, to extend his stay at White Hart Lane and it has since been a matter of finding time to complete the paperwork. Pochettino’s three assistants – Jesús Pérez, Miguel D’Agostino and Toni Jiménez – have also signed extensions to their contracts.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/mauricio-pochettino-signs-new-deal-future-tottenham-2021">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>John Terry to be told by club that Chelsea career is over</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/john-terry-meeting-chelsea-career-over</link>
      <description>• Terry to meet the directors Michael Emenalo and Marina Granovskaia<br />• Terry is suspended for Chelsea’s final game of season<p>John Terry is to meet the Chelsea hierarchy on Thursday to discuss his future at the club, with the captain ready for confirmation he will not be offered new terms to extend his stay at Stamford Bridge into a 19th senior campaign.</p><p>The centre-half’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/07/sunderland-chelsea-premier-league-report">dismissal in stoppage time</a> against Sunderland last weekend means he will not feature again this season, missing Wednesday’s game at Liverpool and the visit of the champions, Leicester City, on the final afternoon. Terry, who has made 703 first-team appearances for Chelsea, opted against travelling to Merseyside on the basis his presence might have provided an unwanted distraction.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/john-terry-meeting-chelsea-career-over">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/charlton-athletic-chief-executive-katrien-meire-fans</link>
      <description>• Katrien Meire has suffered ‘criminal offences’ against her<br />• ‘For the last couple of months, I’ve had extreme abuse’<p>Charlton Athletic’s chief executive has hit out at football supporters, telling a sports conference in London that “sometimes the fans cross the line” in their protests at the way clubs are administered.</p><p>Katrien Meire also claimed that criminal offences have been committed against her after responding to suggestions from the top table that Charlton, Leeds United and Portsmouth were all poorly run clubs.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/charlton-athletic-chief-executive-katrien-meire-fans">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>If you want an example of hubris, look no further than Newcastle’s boardroom | Louise Taylor</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/12/newcastle-relegation-championship-mike-ashley-board-rafael-benitez</link>
      <description>The startling reality is that despite spending £80m on new players this season – only Manchester City invested more – Newcastle have still ended up in this mess<p>So John Carver was right after all. A little over a year ago Newcastle United’s interim manager claimed even a world-class coach would struggle at St James’ Park and, sure enough, Rafael Benítez has vindicated his theory.</p><p>When, two months ago, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/11/newcastle-rafael-benitez-new-manager" title="">Benítez succeeded Steve McClaren,</a> he had 10 games to keep Newcastle in the Premier League and, justifiably, fancied his chances. Nine of those matches later – two won, three lost, four drawn – the Tynesiders are relegated but this costly tumble into the Championship is not remotely the Spaniard’s fault.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/12/newcastle-relegation-championship-mike-ashley-board-rafael-benitez">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Back to the future: how football’s tactical evolution has begun to invoke the past | Jonathan Wilson</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/future-football-tactics-evolution-invoke-the-past</link>
      <description>Leicester and Atlético Madrid found success after discovering opponents had forgotten the answers to counter their old-fashioned tactics – what does this mean for the Barçajax philosophy?<p>For a time, the orthodoxy was that the only way, at least for clubs that saw themselves as part of the elite, was the Barçajax way. Pep Guardiola’s Barcelona were seen as the model, producing football of extraordinary brilliance, pushing the boundaries of what had previously been thought possible in terms of control of possession. Others followed, many of them directed by coaches who had, like Guardiola, been at Barcelona in the late 90s and who represented the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/aug/13/jose-mourinho-louis-van-gaal-barcelona-shaped-seven-top-coaches" title="">blossoming of Johan Cruyff’s ideals into orthodoxy</a>.</p><p>That consensus has collapsed over the past couple of seasons. It’s not just <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/dec/22/devil-and-jose-mourinho" title="">José Mourinho waging his Oedipal war</a> against the club that formed him. Counterattacking is back in vogue. Tactical history is always like this: there have always been cycles of thesis and antithesis, but it’s the route the resulting syntheses are taking that makes this such a fascinating time.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/future-football-tactics-evolution-invoke-the-past">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Everton put Roberto Martínez out of his agony amid the Wigan parallels | Paul Wilson</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/12/everton-roberto-martinez-wigan-parallels</link>
      <description>Despite a successful first season at Goodison, the Spaniard’s tactical failings gradually alienated Everton fans and by the end of his three-year reign he appeared to lose the dressing room too<p>Roberto Martínez cut such a lonely and despondent figure in the television interview studio following the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sunderland-everton-premier-league-match-report" title="">3-0 defeat at Sunderland</a> on Wednesday night it is no surprise Everton have released him early and spared him the ignominy of facing scornful home supporters in the final game of the season against Norwich on Sunday.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/10/roberto-martinez-everton-chelsea" title="">The manager lost the fans some time ago</a> and judging by the last couple of abject performances, lost the dressing room, too. The match at Sunderland, the second time in a week that Everton had provided only token resistance to opponents writing their own headlines, came three years to the day since Martínez’s greatest triumph, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/may/11/manchester-city-wigan-athletic-fa-cup" title="">the FA Cup win with Wigan Athletic</a> that brought him to the Merseyside club’s attention.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/12/everton-roberto-martinez-wigan-parallels">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What was the difference between Jason Koumas and Steven Gerrard? Not talent</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/in-bed-with-maradona/2016/may/12/jason-koumas-steven-gerrard-liverpool-tranmere</link>
      <description><p>As <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/sep/19/steven-gerrard-liverpool-football-interview-donald-mcrae">Steven Gerrard said goodbye to Liverpool</a> as a legend last year, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/apr/25/tranmere-cheltenham-relegated-conference-shrewsbury-plymouth">Jason Koumas was being relegated</a> to the fifth tier. The former team-mates were equally gifted but one won the Champions League and the other never played in a final. Why?</p><p>By <a href="https://twitter.com/leoncbarton">Leon Barton</a> for <a href="http://inbedwithmaradona.com/">In Bed With Maradona</a>, of the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/series/guardian-sport-network">Guardian Sport Network</a></p><p>When Liverpool and the Premier League said goodbye to Steven Gerrard a year ago, there was an avalanche of tributes in the media. It got me thinking about Gerrard’s old friend Jason Koumas, who, in contrast, was relegated from the Football League with Tranmere Rovers around the same time. Someone had to, I suppose. </p><p>I realise it might seem ludicrous to lump a man who won the Champions League, Uefa Cup, two FA Cups, three League Cups and represented England 114 times (encompassing six major tournaments) into the same introduction as a man who never won a trophy – or even played in a final – and played just 34 times for Wales, only once getting anywhere near to an international tournament before ultimately failing. But whenever I read or heard another eulogy for Liverpool’s departing captain, it brought to mind something my cousin – who played alongside Koumas as a youth team player at Tranmere – told me a few years earlier: “Jason had more ability than Steven Gerrard. The problem was ability was all he had.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/in-bed-with-maradona/2016/may/12/jason-koumas-steven-gerrard-liverpool-tranmere">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>West Ham flashpoint brief but shameful on a night not to be forgotten</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/west-ham-flashpoint-shameful-fans-farewell</link>
      <description><p>The game turned out to be a thriller but the image that the minority of fans managed to portray was a long way from the one West Ham had wanted on the night they said farewell to their ground of 112 years</p><p>With the benefit of hindsight, Asif Yasin, who owns Elliott Davis Properties opposite the Boleyn Ground, would not make the same decision again. At 5.30pm on Tuesday he got into his car and tried to drive along Green Street up to the junction with Barking Road. It is a stretch of roughly 100 metres. “I was in my car for an hour and a half,” Yasin says.</p><p>When he reached the corner, he found himself alongside the bus that was carrying the visiting Manchester United players and staff. It was gridlock. And then it happened. In images that quickly hit social media and swirled around the world, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/10/manchester-united-coach-attacked-upton-park-west-ham">a group of West Ham United fans</a> decided to throw an array of things at the stationary vehicle. Yasin was in the midst of the storm.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/west-ham-flashpoint-shameful-fans-farewell">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Adrian Doherty: did Manchester United let down football’s lost genius?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/adrian-doherty-manchester-united-lost-genius</link>
      <description>A new book about the forgotten star who played with Giggs and the Nevilles reveals those closest to him suspect a deliberate process to airbrush him out of the club’s history<p>Of all the profoundly sad and moving passages in the forthcoming book about Adrian Doherty – featuring contributions from Ryan Giggs, the Nevilles, Sir Alex Ferguson and various other names from one of Manchester United’s more glorified eras – perhaps the most poignant part comes in the years when the people closest to this supremely talented boy suspect a deliberate process to airbrush him out of the club’s history.</p><p>“After an awful lot of deliberation, Jimmy, Geraldine and the rest of the Doherty family decided against airing their grievances in this book,” the author, Oliver Kay, explains towards the end of Forever Young. “They do not want a book about their beloved Adrian to end with a ‘slanging match’.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/adrian-doherty-manchester-united-lost-genius">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Previewing the Football League play-offs: how the 12 clubs have fared in the past</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/the-agony-and-the-ecstasy/2016/may/11/football-league-play-offs-championship-league-one-two</link>
      <description><p>How will Brighton respond after their disappointment against Middlesbrough? Will Accrington Stanley recover after falling short on the last day of the season? And will Portsmouth improve on their result against Leicester City in 1993?</p><p>By <a href="https://twitter.com/rcfoster">Richard Foster</a> for <a href="http://www.ockleybooks.co.uk/books/browse-by-category/product/17-the-agony-the-ecstasy-a-comprehensive-history-of-the-football-league-play-offs">The Agony and the Ecstasy</a> of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/series/guardian-sport-network">Guardian Sport Network</a></p><p>An uncertain path lies ahead for fans of the dozen clubs preparing for the play-offs: a path strewn with undulations and plenty of twists and turns. There is nothing straightforward about earning promotion this way. It has become known for a particularly acute brand of cruelty for almost 30 years and emotions will be laid bare in the coming weeks. Here we take a look at how the clubs involved have fared in their previous play-offs appearances.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/the-agony-and-the-ecstasy/2015/nov/23/football-league-play-offs-agony-ecstasy">Chelsea, a curse and Tony Cascarino: lesser-known facts about the play-offs</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/the-agony-and-the-ecstasy/2016/may/11/football-league-play-offs-championship-league-one-two">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Columbus trade Kei Kamara to New England after penalty argument</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/columbus-crew-kei-kamara-trade-new-england-mls-penalty-kick</link>
      <description><ul><li>Kamara’s transfer comes days after penalty spat with Federico Higuain<br></li><li>Revs GM Michael Burns says: ‘Kei is a proven goalscorer in MLS’<br></li></ul><p>Less than a week after a very public spat with his team-mate over who should take a penalty kick, Columbus Crew have agreed to trade Kei Kamara, last season’s leading goalscorer, to New England Revolution for a record fee. The move was finalised just before the end of the primary transfer window.</p><p>The move represents a coup for Revolution – Kamara matched Sebastian Giovinco’s regular-season tally of 22 goals last season to win the Golden Boot – but suggests Columbus were deeply troubled <a href="http://Kamara argues with Federico Higuain">by Kamara’s disagreement with Federico Higuain</a> during last week’s game against Montreal.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/columbus-crew-kei-kamara-trade-new-england-mls-penalty-kick">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Cle Kooiman, the indoor soccer star who became an unlikely hero in Mexico</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/cle-kooiman-indoor-soccer-usa-mexico</link>
      <description><p>The big white guy from southern California was deemed the wrong fit for the skilful, technical Mexican game. But he won over the sceptics, and earned a place on USA’s World Cup roster</p><p>Not many soccer players can say that landing in Mexico’s Ciudad de Juárez was the fulfillment of a childhood dream. But then Cle Kooiman was no ordinary soccer player.</p><p>When Kooiman arrived in Juárez in 1990, he found a sprawling border town of ne million people, most of whom were looking for work in the city’s growing manufacturing industries. These were the halcyon days before Juárez became a byword for murder and drugs, back when this working-class town in the middle of the Chihuahua Desert believed it could spark a nationwide economic recovery. Its ambitions made it the perfect fit for Kooiman, a southern California native with a surfer’s sunny vibe and a chip on his shoulder wide enough to span the Rio Grande.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/cle-kooiman-indoor-soccer-usa-mexico">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>New-look Socceroos squad selected for England friendly in Sunderland</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/new-look-socceroos-squad-selected-for-england-friendly-in-sunderland</link>
      <description><ul><li>Jamie Maclaren, Craig Goodwin and Stefan Mauk called up for first time</li><li>Asia-based Australian players unable to be selected by Ange Postecoglou</li></ul><p>A-League stars Jamie Maclaren, Craig Goodwin and Stefan Mauk headline a new-look Socceroos squad for their high-profile friendly against England at the Stadium of Light in Sunderland on 27 May.</p><p>Unable to select Asia-based players as the match falls outside of a Fifa window, coach Ange Postecoglou has made nine changes to the squad that beat Tajikistan and Jordan in March’s World Cup qualifiers, handing debut caps to Maclaren, Mauk and midfielders Milos Degenek and Brad Inman.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/new-look-socceroos-squad-selected-for-england-friendly-in-sunderland">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/10/spains-gay-referee-football-abuse-jesus-tomillero</link>
      <description>• Jesús Tomillero reaches breaking point 14 months after coming out<br />• Referee in Andalucían regional league ‘cannot take any more’<p>Spain’s first openly gay referee has walked away from the game, insisting he “cannot take any more”.</p><p>Jesús Tomillero, who has been a referee from the age of the 11 and was working near the foot of the Spanish football pyramid in the Andalucían regional league, took the decision after he was subjected to abuse following his decision to give a penalty during a match between Portuense and San Fernando Isleño on Saturday.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/10/spains-gay-referee-football-abuse-jesus-tomillero">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/10/tony-adams-brondby-manager-arsenal</link>
      <description>• Former Arsenal captain is favourite to take charge at Danish club<br />• Adams is leaving post as director of football at Gabala in Azerbaijan<p>Tony Adams is in negotiations with Brondby about becoming their manager.       <description><p>• Manchester United were among clubs interested in Renato Sanches<br>• Hummels leaves Dortmund after eight and a half years</p><p>Bayern Munich have completed the signings of Benfica’s midfielder Renato Sanches and Borussia Dortmund’s defender Mats Hummels.</p><p>The 18-year-old Portuguese international Sanches will cost Bayern €35m plus add-ons while the fee for the Germany defender is undisclosed but believed to be around €30m.     <item>
      <title>Atlético Madrid are a team made for suffering as title bid ends so close to line | Sid Lowe</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/09/atletico-madrid-team-suffering-title-bid-ends-levante-diego-simeone</link>
      <description>A game that seemed impossible to lose for a squad more accustomed to emerging triumphant was duly lost at Levante, along with any chance of La Liga glory, but Diego Simeone remains proud of this season<p>Atlético Madrid slipped into the lead after one minute and 18 seconds and out of the race after 89 minutes and two seconds. The “enthusiasm, hope and perseverance” that Diego Simeone had talked about finally left them in the last minute of the next-to-last week of the season when Giuseppe Rossi scored a winner that gave them no way back. Atlético will not make it to the final day, after all. Top virtually at the start of the day, they were out of it at the end, defeated by the team who were not just bottom but already relegated, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/apr/25/levante-left-needing-miracle-fight-avoid-la-liga-drop">a Second Division side</a>. Levante had nothing to play for. Nor do Atlético Madrid any more. Apart from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/03/bayern-munich-atletico-madrid-champions-league-match-report">that European Cup final</a>, of course, their second in three seasons.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/08/barcelona-real-madrid-la-liga-title-chase">Barcelona and Real Madrid take La Liga title chase to final day</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/09/atletico-madrid-team-suffering-title-bid-ends-levante-diego-simeone">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Luca Toni exits pursued by deserved fanfare and tears in fair Verona | Paolo Bandini</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/09/luca-toni-exits-verona-retires-serie-a-juventus</link>
      <description>The first Italian to win the European Golden Shoe retires from game after helping to beat Serie A champions Juventus with ‘most beautiful goal of my career’<p>Luca Toni has scored some special goals over the past 22 years. <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IYT7Z1O21Ys" title="">A double for Italy against Ukraine</a> in the 2006 World Cup quarter-final, keeping his country on track to win the competition. Thirty-one for <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sz4hAFrXh6U" title="">Fiorentina in the preceding Serie A campaign</a>, making him the first Italian to win the European Golden Shoe. That <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_xLEpElumho" title="">scandalous overhead kick for Vicenza against Bologna</a> back in 2000, during his first season of top-flight football.</p><p>None of those, though, felt as magical to Toni as <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/08/luca-toni-bows-out-with-penalty-for-hellas-verona-in-win-over-juventus" title="">the goal he scored on Sunday night</a>. A goal in a game that mattered not at all.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/09/luca-toni-exits-verona-retires-serie-a-juventus">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>• Manager hurt himself while being chased by striker Davie Selke<br />• ‘He definitely tried to run from me, which isn’t a good idea’<p>Ralf Rangnick’s delight at guiding RB Leipzig to the Bundesliga for the first time in the club’s history was slightly dampened when the former Schalke manager appeared to tear his hamstring during the post-match celebrations.</p><p>Players were presented with giant glasses of beer on the pitch after <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/08/rb-leipzig-promotion-bundesliga" title="">Leipzig’s 2-0 victory over Karlsruhe</a> ensured they will finish the season as second division runners up behind champions Freiburg.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/09/rb-leipzig-ralf-rangnick-hamstring-celebrations">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Why MLS clubs should steer clear of John Terry | Graham Ruthven</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/mls-top-clubs-steer-clear-john-terry</link>
      <description><p>The Chelsea captain is past his best, would cost lots in salary, and do little to dispel the notion of MLS as a retirement home for Europe’s faded stars</p><p>Perhaps John Terry’s American charm offensive started with some words of praise for Chris Wondolowski. Four years ago the Chelsea defender went out of his way to compliment the San Jose striker on his movement throughout the 2012 MLS All-Star game, which Chelsea lost 3-2. Maybe in that moment the former England captain began to think of a life for himself Stateside.</p><p>OK, so Terry probably wasn’t that cynical in his acclaim of Wondolowski, even if his remarks went against the grain of his somewhat toxic caricature. His comments were most likely off the cuff, and maybe even entirely sincere, given the manner in which Wondo so easily lost Terry as he turned home a Thierry Henry cross. With the game played four years ago, the Chelsea man probably wasn’t thinking about a Major League Soccer move just yet.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/mls-top-clubs-steer-clear-john-terry">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>In today’s Fiver: Everton, Bobby M, misbehaving match officials and more</p><p>Newcastle United and Norwich City <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sunderland-everton-premier-league-match-report">were relegated</a> from the Premier League on Wednesday night and their fans immediately began clamouring for their managers to remain in situ. Everton, meanwhile, confirmed a lower-table finish while successfully fulfilling their 37th league fixture, turning up in Sunderland bang on time and in matching uniforms, yet poor old Bobby M still found himself the subject of mass derision.     <item>
      <title>Football teams relegated despite not being in the drop zone all season | The Knowledge</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/football-team-relegated-not-being-in-drop-zone-all-season-the-knowledge</link>
      <description><p>Plus: managers overseeing two relegations in one season, train stations v town size (2) and could Harry Kewell have played for England? Mail your questions to <a href="https://mail.google.com/mail/?view=cm&amp;fs=1&amp;tf=1&amp;to=knowledge@theguardian.com">knowledge@theguardian.com</a> or tweet <a href="https://twitter.com/theknowledge_gu">@TheKnowledge_GU</a></p><p><strong>“Just wanted to ask,”</strong> emails Aniket Joshi, <strong>“have there been any teams relegated on the final day of a league despite never having been in the relegation zone for the rest of the season?”</strong></p><p>The Premier League is often called the most competitive league in the world (of course, it isn’t even the most competitive league in the UK) but if you think this season in England’s top flight was one in which anybody could beat anybody, take a look at the 1908-09 First Division. A similar format – 20 teams, 38 matches for each team – yet the margins between the teams were tighter than a Floridian vote count. Well not quite, but they were close: by the end of the season, just four points separated Woolwich Arsenal in sixth and Manchester City in 19th. City had not been in the dreaded bottom two all season – in fact they had roared to the top of the league on the opening day owing to a 1-0 win against Sunderland (level points then decided by goal average – goals scored divided by goals conceded – thereby rewarding those who scored fewer goals) and had floated about in mid-table ever since, owing to their excellent home record (12 wins from 19, only The Wednesday, Sunderland and champions Newcastle had more) and dismal away record. The polar nature of the club was reflected on the terraces too, with attendances ranging from 40,000 to 3,000 throughout the campaign. Yet come the business end of the season, City were on the brink and lost their final match 1-0 away at Bristol City.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/football-team-relegated-not-being-in-drop-zone-all-season-the-knowledge">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/football/football">Football</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/sport">Sport</category>

    <item>
      <title>Middlesbrough back in the big time with Newcastle on the brink – Football Weekly</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/audio/2016/may/09/middlesborough-back-in-the-big-time-with-newcastle-on-the-brink-football-weekly</link>
      <description><p>Middlesbrough’s draw with Brighton secured promotion back to the Premier League, where it looks like they’ll be replacing Newcastle. Plus, Manchester City’s Champions League prospects are in serious trouble; Swansea wallop West Ham; and John Terry’s last act for Chelsea</p><p>On today’s<strong> Football Weekly</strong> – controversially restored to its normal Monday slot – <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/acjimbo">AC Jimbo</a></strong> is joined by <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/bglendenning">Barry Glendenning</a></strong>, <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/zonal_marking">Michael Cox </a></strong>and <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/simon_burnton">Simon Burnton</a></strong> to answer the burning questions arising from this weekend in the Premier League and beyond.</p><p>We start with the relegation battle. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/07/norwich-manchester-united-premier-league-report">Norwich are all-but-doomed after they lost to Manchester United </a>and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/07/aston-villa-newcastle-premier-league-report">Newcastle probably deserve all that’s coming to them for failing to beat Aston Villa</a> – which all means that<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/07/sunderland-chelsea-premier-league-report"> Sunderland are looking good after beating Chelsea 3-2</a>, which will probably turn out to be <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/07/john-terry-red-card-last-game-for-chelsea">John Terry’s final game for Chelsea</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/audio/2016/may/09/middlesborough-back-in-the-big-time-with-newcastle-on-the-brink-football-weekly">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The Joy of Six: football chants</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/06/the-joy-of-six-football-chants</link>
      <description><p>From Anfield’s unmistakable anthem to Barnsley’s glorious nihilism and existentialism among AFC Wimbledon fans – half a dozen of the best chants</p><p>When the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/apr/26/hillsborough-inquests-jury-says-96-victims-were-unlawfully-killed">jubilant, vindicated and visibly relieved families</a>, friends and supporters of the 96 Liverpool fans recently emerged from the inquest that confirmed what they’d all known for 27 years, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/video/2016/apr/26/hillsborough-victims-families-sing-youll-never-walk-alone-after-verdict-video">there was only ever one song they were likely to sing</a>. There can scarcely have been a more sincere and heartfelt performance of a football chant that is always capable of prompting goosebumps regardless of one’s football allegiances.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/06/the-joy-of-six-football-chants">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>During Saturday’s North West Counties League Premier Division match the Squires Gate player Joe Noblet was denied a goal after his 40-yard thunderbolt flew in off the post, but bounced back off the perimeter fence behind the goal so quickly the hapless officials did not realise what had happened and waved play on.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/13/league-charity-match-twelve-goals-1935-archive</link>
      <description><p><strong>13 May 1935: </strong>Football League team wins 10-2 in a charity match for the King’s Jubilee trust fund</p><p><strong>Football League 10, Irish and Welsh 2</strong><br></p><p>What’s in a name? A great deal in football, it seems. A regrettably thin crowd went to Goodison Park, Liverpool, on Saturday to see two fine teams play a most entertaining match for the <a href="https://uploads.guim.co.uk/2016/05/12/King's_Jubilee_Trust_Fund_2_March_1935.jpeg">King’s Jubilee Trust Fund</a>. Had these teams been labelled “Liverpool” and “Everton” and the match been called “F.A. Cup, sixth-round tie,” the ground would hardly have held the people eager to see it. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/13/league-charity-match-twelve-goals-1935-archive">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Hillsborough victims honoured with freedom of Liverpool</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/13/hillsborough-victims-honoured-freedom-of-liverpool</link>
      <description><p>Council also awards honour to Kenny Dalglish and wife Marina, former bishop James Jones and campaigner Phil Scraton</p><p>The <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/ng-interactive/2016/apr/06/hillsborough-victims-the-96-people-whose-lives-were-cut-short">96 people</a> who died in the Hillsborough disaster in 1989 are to be posthumously awarded the freedom of the city of Liverpool, the local council has announced.</p><p>Kenny Dalglish, the manager of Liverpool FC at the time, and his wife, Marina, are also to be awarded the freedom of the city, along with the former <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/oct/18/hillsborough-panel-interview-james-jones">bishop of Liverpool James Jones</a> and Prof Phil Scraton, a campaigner for the bereaved families’ cause.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/13/hillsborough-victims-honoured-freedom-of-liverpool">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/roberto-martinez-sacked-everton</link>
      <description>• Spaniard spared indignity of further fans’ protests<br />• Everton thank Martínez for his ‘dedication and commitment’<p>Roberto Martínez has been sacked by Everton after three seasons in charge. The club’s new major shareholder, Farhad Moshiri, decided to end Martínez’s tenure following talks with the Goodison Park hierarchy on Thursday and has begun the search for a successor.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/frank-de-boer-leaves-ajax-everton">Frank de Boer to leave Ajax after agent says Dutchman would love Everton job</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/roberto-martinez-sacked-everton">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sunderland 3-0 Everton: Premier League – as it happened</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2016/may/11/sunderland-v-everton-premier-league-live</link>
      <description><p>Sunderland, energetic and effervescent against a miserable Everton, secured their Premier League status at the expense of Norwich City and neighbours Newcastle United.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-11T20:41:17.787Z">9.41pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>The final whistle blows! The Stadium of Light bursts with relief and celebration! Sunderland are deserved winners tonight, and on the basis of their late-season form, deserved Premier League survivors! They’ve sent Norwich City and, of all teams, Newcastle United down to the Championship with Aston Villa! A big smile plays across Sam Allardyce’s face. One can only wonder why. “This is really nice, it’s like winning a title,” smiles Jan Kirchhoff. Congratulations to the Black Cats, and commiserations to Newcastle and Norwich, who will be feeling heartbroken tonight.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sunderland-everton-premier-league-match-report">Sunderland safe after Lamine Koné double sinks crumbling Everton</a> </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-11T20:39:02.907Z">9.39pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>90 min +5:</strong> Mirallas chips over Mannone from the edge of the box, but the ball bounces wide left. Just. Everton have been awful tonight, but they could have had two or three in added time!</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2016/may/11/sunderland-v-everton-premier-league-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/newcastle-united-devastated-relegation-managing-director-lee-charnley</link>
      <description>• Club’s relegation was confirmed by Sunderland’s 3-0 victory over Everton<br />• Charnley: ‘I am truly sorry we have not given you the outcome you deserve’<p>Newcastle United are “devastated” by their relegation from the Premier League, according to the club’s managing director Lee Charnley. <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sunderland-everton-premier-league-match-report" title="">Sunderland’s 3-0 victory at home to Everton</a> confirmed that their north-east neighbours would be playing in the Championship next season, with one game of the Premier League season to go.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sunderland-everton-premier-league-match-report">Sunderland safe after Lamine Koné double sinks crumbling Everton</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/newcastle-united-devastated-relegation-managing-director-lee-charnley">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>A Belgium international belatedly illuminated Anfield, though it was not Christian Benteke with the injury-time equaliser that preserved Liverpool’s unbeaten home run.       <title>Liverpool 1-1 Chelsea: Premier League – as it happened</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2016/may/11/liverpool-v-chelsea-premier-league-live</link>
      <description><p>Christian Benteke’s injury-time equaliser rescued a point for Liverpool after Eden Hazard’s sublime first-half goal</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-11T20:56:31.744Z">9.56pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>We’ll wrap this blog up now.</strong> Here’s a report on the Sunderland v Everton game; we’ll have the Liverpool-Chelsea match report shortly:</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sunderland-everton-premier-league-match-report">Sunderland safe after Lamine Koné double sinks crumbling Everton</a> </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-11T20:54:30.395Z">9.54pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Well, Liverpool finally managed to breach Chelsea’s defence.</strong> They huffed and puffed in the second half without really creating a clear chance, but they kept at it, and the substitute Christian Benteke got his reward in the second minute of stoppage time. Chelsea played pretty well, but didn’t extend themselves in attack after the break, although Pedro might have sealed it with two minutes to go. A decent away point for Chelsea, but they’ll feel it should have been three.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2016/may/11/liverpool-v-chelsea-premier-league-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/norwich-city-watford-premier-league-match-report</link>
      <description><p>After winning the match but losing the fight for survival Alex Neil said Norwich’s relegation was largely his fault. “When you go up from the Championship everyone says how great you are and you sit there and take the plaudits, so when the team goes down I’ll take the brunt of the blame,” said the Scot. But most Norwich fans made it clear they disagree.</p><p>The way the Carrow Road crowd serenaded Neil during a lap of appreciation following an entertaining but ultimately futile win over Watford showed that most Norwich supporters seemingly want the 34-year-old to stay in charge and lead the club to another promotion, having <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/may/25/alex-neil-promotion-premier-league-norwich-middlesbrough" title="">guided the team into the Premier League</a> following his appointment in January 2015.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/norwich-city-watford-premier-league-match-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>David Gold says West Ham trouble proved need for Olympic Stadium</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/david-gold-west-ham-trouble-olympic-stadium</link>
      <description>• West Ham co-owner promises to ban offenders for life<br />• ‘The new stadium has five train stations and overspill areas’<p>David Gold has said that the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/10/manchester-united-coach-attacked-upton-park-west-ham" title="">trouble which marred West Ham United’s final game</a> at Upton Park <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/10/west-ham-manchester-united-premier-league-report-upton-park" title="">against Manchester United</a> on Tuesday night highlighted why the club had to move on to the Olympic Stadium. He and West Ham’s other co-owner, David Sullivan, apologised to United for the attack on their team bus beforehand, with Sullivan promising to ban for life any identifiable perpetrators.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/west-ham-flashpoint-shameful-fans-farewell">West Ham flashpoint brief but shameful on a night not to be forgotten</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/david-gold-west-ham-trouble-olympic-stadium">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Fiver | A kids’ birthday party in Laser Quest circa 1991</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/the-fiver-state-of-west-ham-</link>
      <description><p>In today’s Fiver: a post-match party abomination, Eamonn Holmes and Falkirk</p><p>The Fiver’s short-term memory has been badly affected by Purple Tin, but we don’t remember West Ham creating this much fuss when they moved from Upton Park to whatever the Boleyn Ground is. But this time, the club’s exit to the tax haven that is The People’s Stadium of East London has sparked all manner of hoo-ha, with supporters celebrating the club’s new status as a government asset by pelting the Manchester United bus with empty bottles of Rowdiness Enabler in the run-up to the The Last Game At The Boleyn Ground.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/the-fiver-state-of-west-ham-">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Arsenal’s Danny Welbeck faces nine months out after knee surgery</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/arsenal-danny-welbeck-nine-months-out-knee-surgery</link>
      <description>• Arsenal confirm forward has had operation to his right knee<br />• Club say recovery period likely to keep Welbeck out until February<p>Danny Welbeck is expected to be out for nine months after surgery to his right knee, Arsenal have announced. The forward sustained the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/09/arsenal-fear-danny-welbeck-miss-euro-2016-injury" title="">injury at Manchester City</a> on Sunday and scans revealed “significant cartilage damage”, the club said.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/who-scored-blog/2016/may/10/danny-welbeck-england-euro-2016-carroll-deeney-defoe">Who should take Danny Welbeck's place in the England squad at Euro 2016?</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/arsenal-danny-welbeck-nine-months-out-knee-surgery">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/gallery/2015/jun/27/the-calcio-storico-the-most-brutal-sport-on-earth-in-pictures</link>
      <description><p class="p1" data-dropid="0">The Calcio Storico – ‘historic football’ – is an ancient form of football from the 16th century, which originated from the ancient roman ‘harpastum’, and is played in teams of 27, using both feet and hands.
